title: Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex
text:
Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, (Henry Charles Albert David; born 15 September 1984), is a member of the <a href="British%20royal%20family">British royal family</a>. As the younger son of <a href="Charles%2C%20Prince%20of%20Wales">Charles, Prince of Wales</a>, and <a href="Lady%20Diana%20Spencer">Lady Diana Spencer</a>, he is sixth in the <a href="Succession%20to%20the%20British%20throne%23Current%20line%20of%20succession">line of succession to the British throne</a>.
Born in <a href="St%20Mary%27s%20Hospital%2C%20London">St Mary's Hospital, London</a>, Harry was educated at <a href="Wetherby%20School">Wetherby School</a>, <a href="Ludgrove%20School">Ludgrove School</a>, and <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>. He spent parts of his <a href="gap%20year">gap year</a> in Australia and <a href="Lesotho">Lesotho</a>, then underwent officer training at the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%20Sandhurst">Royal Military Academy Sandhurst</a>. He was commissioned as a <a href="Cornet%20%28rank%29">cornet</a> into the <a href="Blues%20and%20Royals">Blues and Royals</a>, serving temporarily with his brother <a href="Prince%20William">William</a> and completed training as a troop leader. In 2007–2008, he <a href="Operation%20Herrick">served for over ten weeks</a> in <a href="Helmand%20Province">Helmand Province</a>, Afghanistan. He returned to Afghanistan for a 20-week deployment in 2012–2013 with the <a href="Army%20Air%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Army Air Corps</a>. In June 2015, he resigned from the army.
Harry launched the <a href="Invictus%20Games">Invictus Games</a> in 2014 and remains the patron of its foundation. He also gives patronage to several other organisations, including the <a href="HALO%20Trust">HALO Trust</a> and <a href="Walking%20With%20The%20Wounded">Walking With The Wounded</a>. To encourage people to open up about their <a href="mental%20health">mental health</a> issues, Harry, alongside the <a href="Prince%20William%2C%20Duke%20of%20Cambridge">Duke</a> and <a href="Catherine%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Cambridge">Duchess of Cambridge</a>, initiated the mental health awareness campaign "Heads Together" in April 2016.
In 2018, Harry was made <a href="Duke%20of%20Sussex">Duke of Sussex</a> prior to his <a href="Wedding%20of%20Prince%20Harry%20and%20Meghan%20Markle">wedding</a> to American actress <a href="Meghan%20Markle">Meghan Markle</a>. In January 2020, the couple <a href="Megxit">stepped down</a> as senior members of the royal family and moved to the Duchess's native <a href="Southern%20California">Southern California</a>. In October 2020, they launched <a href="Archewell%20Inc.">Archewell Inc.</a>, an American public organisation that focuses on <a href="non-profit">non-profit</a> activities and creative media ventures. They have two children, <a href="Archie%20Mountbatten-Windsor">Archie</a> and <a href="Lilibet%20Mountbatten-Windsor">Lilibet Mountbatten-Windsor</a>.
Early life.
Prince Harry was born in the Lindo Wing of <a href="St%20Mary%27s%20Hospital%2C%20London">St Mary's Hospital</a> in <a href="Paddington">Paddington</a>, London, on 15 September 1984 at 4:20 pm as the second child of <a href="Charles%2C%20Prince%20of%20Wales">Charles, Prince of Wales</a> (<a href="heir%20apparent">heir apparent</a> to the <a href="British%20throne">British throne</a>), and <a href="Diana%2C%20Princess%20of%20Wales">Diana, Princess of Wales</a>. He was christened Henry Charles Albert David on 21 December 1984 at <a href="St%20George%27s%20Chapel%2C%20Windsor%20Castle">St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle</a>, by the <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a>, <a href="Robert%20Runcie">Robert Runcie</a>. Growing up, he was referred to as "Harry" by family, friends, and the public. Harry and his elder brother, <a href="Prince%20William">William</a>, were raised at <a href="Kensington%20Palace">Kensington Palace</a> in London, and <a href="Highgrove%20House">Highgrove House</a> in <a href="Gloucestershire">Gloucestershire</a>. Diana wanted him and his brother to have a broader range of experiences and a better understanding of ordinary life than previous royal children. She took them to venues that ranged from <a href="Walt%20Disney%20World">Walt Disney World</a> and <a href="McDonald%27s">McDonald's</a> to <a href="AIDS">AIDS clinics</a> and homeless shelters. He began accompanying his parents on official visits at an early age; his first overseas tour was with his parents to Italy in 1985. He also travelled with his family to <a href="Canada">Canada</a> in 1991 and 1998.
Harry's parents divorced in 1996. <a href="Death%20of%20Diana%2C%20Princess%20of%20Wales">His mother died</a> in a car crash in Paris the following year. Harry and William were staying with their father at <a href="Balmoral%20Castle">Balmoral</a> at the time, and the Prince of Wales told his sons about their mother's death. At his <a href="Funeral%20of%20Diana%2C%20Princess%20of%20Wales">mother's funeral</a>, Harry, then 12, accompanied his father, brother, paternal grandfather, and maternal uncle, <a href="Charles%20Spencer%2C%209th%20Earl%20Spencer">Charles Spencer, 9th Earl Spencer</a>, in walking behind the funeral cortège from Kensington Palace to <a href="Westminster%20Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>.
Education.
Like his father and brother, Harry was educated at <a href="independent%20school%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">independent schools</a>. He started at London's Jane Mynors' nursery school and the pre-preparatory <a href="Wetherby%20School">Wetherby School</a>. Following this, he attended <a href="Ludgrove%20School">Ludgrove School</a> in Berkshire. After passing entrance exams, he was admitted to <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>. The decision to place Harry at Eton went against the past practice of the <a href="Mountbatten-Windsor">Mountbatten-Windsor</a>s to send children to <a href="Gordonstoun">Gordonstoun</a>, which Harry's grandfather, father, two uncles, and two cousins had attended. It did, however, see Harry follow in his older brother's footsteps and the Spencer family, as both Diana's father and brother attended Eton.
In June 2003, Harry completed his education at Eton with two <a href="Advanced%20Level%20%28UK%29">A-Levels</a>, achieving a grade B in art and D in geography, having decided to drop history of art after AS level. He has been described as "a top tier athlete", having played competitive <a href="polo">polo</a> and <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>. One of his former teachers, Sarah Forsyth, has asserted that he was a "weak student" and that staff at Eton conspired to help him cheat on examinations. Both Eton and Harry denied the claims. While a tribunal made no ruling on the cheating claim, it "accepted the prince had received help in preparing his A-level 'expressive' project, which he needed to pass to secure his place at Sandhurst." Harry also joined the <a href="Combined%20Cadet%20Force">Combined Cadet Force</a> while studying at Eton and was made cadet officer in his final year, leading the corps' annual parade at the Eton tattoo.
After school, Harry took a <a href="gap%20year">gap year</a>, during which he spent time in Australia working as a <a href="Jackaroo%20%28trainee%29">jackaroo</a> on a cattle station, and participating in the Young England vs Young Australia Polo Test match. He also travelled to <a href="Lesotho">Lesotho</a>, where he worked with orphaned children and produced the documentary film "The Forgotten Kingdom".
Military career.
Sandhurst; Blues and Royals; deployment to Afghanistan.
Harry entered the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%20Sandhurst">Royal Military Academy Sandhurst</a> on 8 May 2005, where he was known as Officer Cadet Wales, and joined the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%20Sandhurst%23Organisation">Alamein Company</a>. In April 2006, Harry completed his officer training and was commissioned as a <a href="Cornet%20%28military%20rank%29">Cornet</a> (<a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a>) in the <a href="Blues%20and%20Royals">Blues and Royals</a>, a regiment of the <a href="Household%20Cavalry">Household Cavalry</a> in the British Army. On 13 April 2008, when he reached two years' seniority, Harry was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a>.
In 2006, it was announced that Harry's unit was scheduled to be deployed in Iraq the following year. A public debate ensued as to whether he should serve there. Defence Secretary <a href="John%20Reid%2C%20Baron%20Reid%20of%20Cardowan">John Reid</a> said that he should be allowed to serve on the front line of battle zones. Harry agreed saying, "If they said 'no, you can't go front line' then I wouldn't drag my sorry ass through Sandhurst and I wouldn't be where I am now." The <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Ministry of Defence</a> and <a href="Clarence%20House">Clarence House</a> made a joint announcement on 22 February 2007 that Harry would be deployed with his regiment to Iraq, as part of the <a href="1st%20Mechanized%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">1st Mechanised Brigade</a> of the <a href="3rd%20Mechanised%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">3rd Mechanised Division</a>a move supported by Harry, who had stated that he would leave the army if he was told to remain in safety while his regiment went to war. He said: "There's no way I'm going to put myself through Sandhurst and then sit on my arse back home while my boys are out fighting for their country."
The head of the British army at the time, <a href="Richard%20Dannatt%2C%20Baron%20Dannatt">General Sir Richard Dannatt</a>, said on 30 April 2007 that he had personally decided that Harry would serve with his unit in Iraq as a troop commander, and Harry was scheduled for deployment in May or June 2007 to patrol the <a href="Maysan%20Governorate">Maysan Governorate</a>. By 16 May, however, Dannatt announced that Harry would not serve in Iraq; concerns included Harry being a high-value target (as several threats by various groups had already been made against him) and the dangers the soldiers around him would face should any attempt be made on his life or if he was captured. Clarence House made public Harry's disappointment with the decision, though he said he would abide by it.
In early June 2007, it was reported that Harry had arrived in Canada to train alongside soldiers of the <a href="Canadian%20Forces">Canadian Forces</a> and British Army, at <a href="CFB%20Suffield">CFB Suffield</a> near <a href="Medicine%20Hat%2C%20Alberta">Medicine Hat, Alberta</a>. It was said that this was in preparation for a <a href="tour%20of%20duty">tour of duty</a> in Afghanistan, where Canadian and British forces were participating in the <a href="NATO">NATO</a>-led <a href="War%20in%20Afghanistan%20%282001%E2%80%93present%29">Afghan War</a>.
This was confirmed in February of the following year, when the British Ministry of Defence revealed that Harry had been secretly deployed as a <a href="Forward%20Air%20Controller">Forward Air Controller</a> to <a href="Helmand%20Province">Helmand Province</a> in Afghanistan for the previous ten weeks. The revelation came after the medianotably, German newspaper "<a href="Bild">Bild</a>" and Australian magazine "<a href="New%20Idea">New Idea</a>"breached the blackout placed over the information by the Canadian and British authorities. He was immediately pulled out due to the fear that the media coverage would put his security and the security of fellow soldiers at risk. It was later reported that Harry helped <a href="Brigade%20of%20Gurkhas">Gurkha</a> troops repel an attack from <a href="Taliban">Taliban</a> insurgents, and performed patrol duty in hostile areas while in Afghanistan.
His tour made Harry the first member of the <a href="British%20royal%20family">British royal family</a> to serve in a war zone since his uncle, <a href="Prince%20Andrew%2C%20Duke%20of%20York">Prince Andrew</a>, who flew helicopters during the <a href="Falklands%20War">Falklands War</a>. For his service, his aunt, <a href="Princess%20Anne">Princess Anne</a>, presented Harry with an <a href="Operational%20Service%20Medal%20for%20Afghanistan">Operational Service Medal for Afghanistan</a> at the <a href="Combermere%20Barracks">Combermere Barracks</a> in May 2008.
Army Air Corps and second deployment to Afghanistan.
In October 2008, it was announced that Harry would follow his brother, father and uncle in learning to fly military helicopters. Harry attended the <a href="Defence%20Helicopter%20Flying%20School">Defence Helicopter Flying School</a> at <a href="RAF%20Shawbury">RAF Shawbury</a>, where he joined his brother. Prince Charles presented him with his flying <a href="Aircrew%20brevet">brevet</a> (wings) on 7 May 2010 at a ceremony at the Army Air Corps Base (AAC), <a href="Middle%20Wallop">Middle Wallop</a>. Harry was awarded his Apache Flying Badge on 14 April 2011. On 16 April 2011, it was announced that Harry had been promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a>. In June 2011, Clarence House announced that Harry would be available for deployment in current operations in Afghanistan as an Apache helicopter pilot. The final decision rested with the Ministry of Defence's senior commanders, including principally the <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20Defence%20Staff%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Chief of the Defence Staff</a> in consultation with the wishes of Harry, the Prince of Wales, and the Queen. In October, he was transferred to a US military base in California to complete his helicopter gunship training. This final phase included live-fire training and "environmental and judgment training" at naval and air force facilities in California and Arizona. In the same month, it was reported that Harry was top of his class in extensive training undertaken at the <a href="Naval%20Air%20Facility%20El%20Centro">Naval Air Facility</a>, <a href="El%20Centro%2C%20California">El Centro, California</a>. While training in Southern California, he spent time in <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego</a>. In November 2011, Harry returned to England. He went to <a href="Wattisham%20Airfield">Wattisham Airfield</a> in Suffolk, in the east of England, to complete his training to fly Apache helicopters.
On 7 September 2012, Harry arrived at <a href="Camp%20Bastion">Camp Bastion</a> in southern Afghanistan as part of the 100-strong <a href="Army%20Air%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29%23Regiments">662 Squadron, 3 Regiment, Army Air Corps</a>, to begin a four-month combat tour as a co-pilot and gunner for an Apache helicopter. On 10 September, within days of arriving in Afghanistan, it was reported that the Taliban had threatened his life. Taliban spokesman <a href="Zabiullah%20Mujahid">Zabiullah Mujahid</a> spoke to <a href="Reuters">Reuters</a> and was quoted as saying: "We are using all our strength to get rid of him, either by killing or kidnapping." He added, "We have informed our commanders in Helmand to do whatever they can to eliminate him." On 21 January 2013, it was announced that Harry was returning from a 20-week deployment in Afghanistan. On 8 July 2013, the Ministry of Defence announced that Harry had successfully qualified as an Apache aircraft commander. Harry compared operating the Apache's weapons systems in <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> to playing video games. He also discussed killing insurgents while piloting his Apache helicopter, and added "we fire when we have to, take a life to save a life, but essentially we're more of a deterrent than anything else".
HQ London District and Invictus Games.
On 17 January 2014, the Ministry of Defence announced that Harry had completed his attachment to 3 Regiment Army Air Corps, and would take up a staff officer role, <a href="Staff%20%28military%29%23British%20Army%20staff">SO3</a> (Defence Engagement) in HQ London District. His responsibilities would include helping to co-ordinate significant projects and commemorative events involving the Army in London. He was based at <a href="Horse%20Guards%20%28building%29">Horse Guards</a> in central London.
On 6 March 2014, Harry launched <a href="Invictus%20Games">Invictus Games</a>, a <a href="Paralympic%20Games">Paralympic</a>-style sporting event for injured servicemen and women, which was held on 10–14 September 2014. Harry met British hopefuls for the Invictus Games at <a href="Tedworth%20House">Tedworth House</a> in Wiltshire for the start of the selection process on 29 April 2014. On 15 May 2014, Harry attended a ticket sale launch for Invictus Games at BT Tower, from where he tweeted on the Invictus Games' official Twitter account as the president of the Games. To promote the Games, he was interviewed by <a href="BBC%20Radio%202">BBC Radio 2</a>'s <a href="Chris%20Evans%20%28presenter%29">Chris Evans</a> along with two Invictus Games hopefuls. He said: "[The Invictus Games] is basically my full-time job at the moment, making sure that we pull this off." The show aired on 31 July 2014. Harry later wrote an article in "<a href="The%20Sunday%20Times">The Sunday Times</a>" about his experiences in Afghanistan: how they had inspired him to help injured personnel and how, after the trip to the <a href="Warrior%20Games">Warrior Games</a>, he had vowed to create the Invictus Games. Harry and officials attended the British Armed Forces Team announcement for Invictus Games at Potters Field Park in August 2014. As president of the Invictus Games, he attended all events related to the Games from 8 to 14 September 2014.
In January 2015, it was reported that Harry would take on a new role in supporting wounded service personnel by working alongside members of the London District's Personal Recovery Unit for the MOD's Defence Recovery Capability scheme to ensure that wounded personnel have adequate recovery plans. The palace confirmed weeks later that the scheme was established in partnership with Help for Heroes and the Royal British Legion. In late January 2015, Harry visited The Battle Back Centre set up by the Royal British Legion, and Fisher House UK at the <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20Hospital%20Birmingham">Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham</a>. A partnership between <a href="Help%20for%20Heroes">Help for Heroes</a>, the <a href="Fisher%20House%20Foundation">Fisher House Foundation</a> and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham (QEHB) Charity created the Centre. Fisher House Foundation is one of the Invictus Games' sponsors. In February and March 2015, Harry visited Phoenix House in <a href="Catterick%20Garrison">Catterick Garrison</a>, North Yorkshire, a recovery centre run by <a href="Help%20for%20Heroes">Help for Heroes</a>. He also visited <a href="Merville%20Barracks">Merville Barracks</a> in <a href="Colchester">Colchester</a>, where Chavasse VC House Personnel Recovery Centre is located, run by Help for Heroes in partnership with the Ministry of Defence and Royal British Legion.
Secondment to Australian Defence Force.
On 17 March 2015, Kensington Palace announced that Harry would leave the Armed Forces in June. Before then, he would spend four weeks throughout April and May at army barracks in Darwin, Perth and Sydney whilst seconded to the <a href="Australian%20Defence%20Force">Australian Defence Force</a> (ADF). After leaving the Army, while considering his future, he would return to work in a voluntary capacity with the Ministry of Defence, supporting Case Officers in the Ministry's Recovery Capability Programme. He would be working with both those who administer and receive physical and mental care within the London District area.
On 6 April 2015, Harry reported for duty to Australia's Chief of the Defence Force, Air Chief Marshal <a href="Mark%20Binskin">Mark Binskin</a> at the Royal Military College, Duntroon in Canberra, Australia. Harry flew to <a href="Darwin%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Darwin</a> later that day to begin his month-long secondment to the ADF's 1st Brigade. His visit included detachments to <a href="NORFORCE">NORFORCE</a> as well as to an aviation unit. While in <a href="Perth%2C%20Australia">Perth</a>, he trained with Special Air Service Regiment (SASR), participating in the SASR selection course, including a fitness test and a physical training session with SASR selection candidates. He also joined SASR members in Perth for live-fire shooting exercises with numerous Special Forces weapons at a variety of ranges. Harry completed an insertion training exercise using a rigid-hull inflatable boat. In Sydney, he undertook urban operations training with the 2nd Commando Regiment. Training activities included remotely detonating an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) and <a href="Abseiling">rappelling</a> from a building. He also spent time flying over Sydney as co-pilot of an Army <a href="Sikorsky%20UH-60%20Black%20Hawk">Black Hawk</a> helicopter and participated in counter-terrorism training in Sydney Harbour with <a href="Royal%20Australian%20Navy">Royal Australian Navy</a> clearance divers.
Harry's attachment with the ADF ended on 8 May 2015, and on 19 June 2015 he resigned his short service commission.
Post-military service.
Since leaving the army, Harry has been closely involved with the armed forces through the Invictus Games, honorary military appointments and other official engagements. On 19 December 2017, he succeeded his grandfather <a href="Prince%20Philip">Prince Philip</a> as the <a href="Captain%20General%20Royal%20Marines">Captain General</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Marines">Royal Marines</a>. In May 2018, he was promoted to the <a href="substantive%20rank">substantive rank</a>s of <a href="Lieutenant%20Commander">Lieutenant Commander</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>, <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Major</a> of the British Army and <a href="Squadron%20Leader">Squadron Leader</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a>.
On 18 January 2020, Buckingham Palace announced that agreement had been reached for Harry "to step back from Royal duties, including official military appointments". In February 2021, the Palace confirmed that the Duke would give up his position as Captain General of the Royal Marines and hand back all the other honorary military appointments.
Personal life.
Bachelorhood.
<a href="Chelsy%20Davy">Chelsy Davy</a>, the daughter of Zimbabwean, South Africa-based businessman Charles Davy, was referred to as Harry's girlfriend in an interview conducted for his 21st birthday, and Harry said he "would love to tell everyone how amazing she is but once I start talking about that, I have left myself open... There is truth and there is lies and unfortunately I cannot get the truth across." Davy was present when Harry received his <a href="Operational%20Service%20Medal%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Operational Service Medal</a> for Afghanistan and also attended his graduation ceremony when he received his flying wings from his father. In early 2009, it was reported the pair had parted ways after a relationship that had lasted for five years.
In May 2012, Harry's cousin <a href="Princess%20Eugenie">Princess Eugenie</a> introduced him to <a href="Cressida%20Bonas">Cressida Bonas</a>, an actress and model who is the granddaughter of <a href="Edward%20Curzon%2C%206th%20Earl%20Howe">Edward Curzon, 6th Earl Howe</a>. On 30 April 2014, it was reported that the couple had parted amicably.
Marriage and fatherhood.
In July 2016, Prince Harry began a relationship with American actress <a href="Meghan%20Markle">Meghan Markle</a>. In November, the prince directed his communications secretary to release a statement on his behalf to express personal concern about pejorative and false comments made about his girlfriend by <a href="mainstream%20media">mainstream media</a> and <a href="internet%20trolls">internet trolls</a>. In September 2017, Prince Harry and Markle first appeared together in public at the <a href="Invictus%20Games">Invictus Games</a> in Toronto. Their engagement was announced on 27 November 2017 by Harry's father Prince Charles. The announcement prompted generally positive comments about having a mixed-race person as a member of the royal family, especially in regard to Commonwealth countries with populations of blended or native ancestry. On 19 May 2018, the <a href="Wedding%20of%20Prince%20Harry%20and%20Meghan%20Markle">marriage ceremony</a> was held at <a href="St%20George%27s%20Chapel%2C%20Windsor%20Castle">St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle</a>. The couple later revealed in the 2021 television interview "<a href="Oprah%20with%20Meghan%20and%20Harry">Oprah with Meghan and Harry</a>" that there was a private exchange of vows 3 days before with the Archbishop of Canterbury in their garden. However, this earlier exchange of vows was not an official religious or <a href="Marriage%20in%20England%20and%20Wales">legally recognised marriage</a>.
It was reportedly agreed in advance that excess funds generated from the <a href="BBC">BBC</a> broadcast of the wedding ceremony would go to a charity chosen by the newlywed couple. In April 2020, Feeding Britain (which provides food packages to families in food poverty) was nominated to receive £90,000 from the BBC.
The Duke and Duchess initially lived at <a href="Nottingham%20Cottage">Nottingham Cottage</a> in London, on the grounds of Kensington Palace. They then moved to <a href="Frogmore%20Cottage">Frogmore Cottage</a> in the <a href="Home%20Park%2C%20Windsor">Home Park</a> of <a href="Windsor%20Castle">Windsor Castle</a>. The <a href="Crown%20Estate">Crown Estate</a> refurbished the cottage at a cost of £2.4 million, paid out of the <a href="Sovereign%20Grant">Sovereign Grant</a>, with the Duke later reimbursing expenses beyond restoration and ordinary maintenance. On 6 May 2019, the Duke and Duchess's son <a href="Archie%20Mountbatten-Windsor">Archie Mountbatten-Windsor</a> was born. Their office was moved to Buckingham Palace and officially closed on 31 March 2020 when the Sussexes ceased "undertaking official engagements in support of the Queen". After some months in Canada and the United States, the couple bought a house in June 2020 on the former estate of <a href="Riven%20Rock%2C%20Montecito">Riven Rock</a> in <a href="Montecito%2C%20California">Montecito, California</a>, where they own a <a href="chicken%20coop">chicken coop</a> with hens rescued from a factory farm. The next month, the Duchess suffered a <a href="miscarriage">miscarriage</a>. On 4 June 2021, their daughter <a href="Lilibet%20Mountbatten-Windsor">Lilibet Mountbatten-Windsor</a> was born.
Harry is godfather to "five or six" children, including the daughters of Major Nicholas van Cutsem, the son of <a href="Hugh%20van%20Cutsem">Hugh van Cutsem</a>, and Jake Warren, his mother's godson, whose father is the Queen's horse racing manager. He became godfather to <a href="Charlie%20van%20Straubenzee">Charlie van Straubenzee</a>'s firstborn daughter in May 2020.
Wealth and inheritance.
At the time of the announcement of Harry and Meghan's decision to "step back" as senior members of the royal family in 2020, 95% of the couple's income derived from the £2.3 million given to them annually by Harry's father, Charles, as part of his income from the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Cornwall">Duchy of Cornwall</a>.
Harry and his brother William inherited the "bulk" of the £12.9 million left by their mother on their respective 30th birthdays, a figure that had grown since her 1997 death to £10 million each in 2014. In 2002, "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>" reported that Harry would also share with his brother a payment of £4.9 million from trust funds established by their great-grandmother, <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20The%20Queen%20Mother">Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother</a>, on their respective 21st birthdays and would share a payment of £8 million upon their respective 40th birthdays. Harry's personal wealth was estimated at £30 million by "<a href="The%20Daily%20Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a>" in 2020.
In 2014, Harry and William inherited their <a href="Wedding%20dress%20of%20Lady%20Diana%20Spencer">mother's wedding dress</a> along with many other of her personal possessions, including dresses, diamond tiaras, jewels, letters, and paintings. The brothers also received the original lyrics and score of "<a href="Candle%20in%20the%20Wind%201997">Candle in the Wind</a>" by <a href="Bernie%20Taupin">Bernie Taupin</a> and <a href="Elton%20John">Elton John</a> as performed by John at Diana's funeral.
Health.
In 2002, it was reported that with Charles's encouragement Harry had paid a visit to a drugs rehabilitation unit to talk to drug addicts after it emerged that he had been smoking cannabis and drinking at his father's Highgrove House and at a local pub. In 2017, Harry acknowledged that with the support of his brother he sought <a href="Grief%20counseling">counselling</a> years after his mother's death, stating: "It's all about timing. And for me personally, my brother, you know, bless him, he was a huge support to me. He kept saying this is not right, this is not normal, you need to talk to [someone] about stuff, it's OK". Harry added that he struggled with aggression, suffered from <a href="anxiety">anxiety</a> during royal engagements, and was "very close to a complete breakdown on numerous occasions". In an episode of "<a href="Armchair%20Expert">Armchair Expert</a>", he attributed his mental health issues to the ineffective parenting style of previous generations and to the "genetic pain and suffering" passed down in his family, adding that his issues stemmed from "the pain or suffering that perhaps my father or my parents had suffered".
Political views.
Members of the British royal family are politically neutral by convention. However, in September 2020, Harry and his wife released a video addressing American voters to "reject hate speech, misinformation and online negativity" in the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2020 United States presidential election</a>, which was seen by some as an implicit endorsement of <a href="Joe%20Biden">Joe Biden</a>.
Harry identifies as a <a href="feminist">feminist</a>. As part of an interview with <a href="Gloria%20Steinem">Gloria Steinem</a> in August 2020, he was quoted as saying "You know that I'm a feminist too, right, Gloria? It's really important to me that you know that."
In May 2021, Harry was a guest on <a href="Dax%20Shepard">Dax Shepard</a> and <a href="Monica%20Padman">Monica Padman</a>'s podcast "<a href="Armchair%20Expert">Armchair Expert</a>" during which he talked about the freedom of speech and laws related to it in the United States, stating "I've got so much I want to say about the <a href="First%20Amendment%20to%20the%20United%20States%20Constitution">First Amendment</a> as I sort of understand it, but it is bonkers." He added that it was "a huge subject and one which [he didn't] understand", emphasising that one could "capitalise or exploit what's not said rather than uphold what is said." The comments were met by backlash from conservative Americans and Britons, prompting figures such as <a href="Ted%20Cruz">Ted Cruz</a>, <a href="Dan%20Crenshaw">Dan Crenshaw</a>, <a href="Nigel%20Farage">Nigel Farage</a>, <a href="Candace%20Owens">Candace Owens</a>, <a href="Jack%20Posobiec">Jack Posobiec</a>, and <a href="Laura%20Ingraham">Laura Ingraham</a> to criticise him publicly.
In November 2021, in a panel at "<a href="Wired%20%28magazine%29">Wired</a>"s Re:Wired Conference, Harry claimed that a day before the January <a href="2021%20United%20States%20Capitol%20attack">2021 United States Capitol attack</a> he emailed <a href="Jack%20Dorsey">Jack Dorsey</a>, CEO of <a href="Twitter">Twitter</a>, and 'warned' of potential civil unrest, but had not received a response. He added that he and Meghan were no longer on social media, and would avoid it "until things change". In the same month, <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative</a> politician and <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">MP</a> <a href="Johnny%20Mercer%20%28politician%29">Johnny Mercer</a>, who was leading the efforts to waive visa fees for foreign-born UK veterans and their families, announced in the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Commons</a> that the Duke of Sussex was supportive of their proposal and viewed it as "morally right" and not as "a political intervention".
Public life.

The new household released a statement announcing they had established their own office at nearby <a href="St%20James%27s%20Palace">St James's Palace</a> to look after their public, military and charitable activities. In March 2012, Harry led an official visit to <a href="Belize">Belize</a> as part of the <a href="Diamond%20Jubilee%20of%20Elizabeth%20II">Queen's Diamond Jubilee</a> celebrations. He continued to the <a href="Bahamas">Bahamas</a> and <a href="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>, where the Prime Minister, <a href="Portia%20Simpson-Miller">Portia Simpson-Miller</a>, was considering initiating a process of turning Jamaica into a republic. He then visited <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> to attend the GREAT Campaign. Harry also played <a href="tambourine">tambourine</a> and took part in the music video for the song "<a href="Sing%20%28Gary%20Barlow%20song%29">Sing</a>", which was released in May 2012 to commemorate the Diamond Jubilee.
Between 9 and 15 May 2013, he made an official visit to the United States. The tour promoted the rehabilitation of injured American and UK troops, publicised his own charities and supported British interests. It included engagements in Washington, DC, Colorado, New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut. He met survivors of <a href="Hurricane%20Sandy">Hurricane Sandy</a> in New Jersey. In October 2013, he undertook his first official tour of Australia, attending the <a href="International%20Fleet%20Review%202013">International Fleet Review</a> at <a href="Sydney%20Harbour">Sydney Harbour</a>. He also paid a visit to the Australian SAS HQ in <a href="Perth">Perth</a>. In May 2014, he visited Estonia and Italy. He also attended a reception at the Estonian Parliament and a <a href="NATO">NATO</a> military exercise. In Italy, Harry attended commemorations of the 70th anniversary of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Monte%20Cassino">Monte Cassino battles</a>, in which Polish, Commonwealth and British troops fought. On 6 November 2014, he opened the <a href="Field%20of%20Remembrance">Field of Remembrance</a> at <a href="Westminster%20Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>, a task usually performed by Prince Philip.
Before reporting for duty to the Australian Defence Force (ADF), Harry visited the <a href="Australian%20War%20Memorial">Australian War Memorial</a> in <a href="Canberra">Canberra</a> on 6 April 2015. On 7 May 2015, he made a farewell walkabout at the <a href="Sydney%20Opera%20House">Sydney Opera House</a> and visited <a href="Macquarie%20University%20Hospital">Macquarie University Hospital</a>. On 24–25 April 2015, he joined his father in Turkey to attend commemorations of the centenary of the <a href="Gallipoli%20Campaign">Gallipoli Campaign</a>. On 26 November 2015, as patron of Sentebale, Harry travelled to Lesotho to attend the opening of the Mamohato Children's Centre. He visited Cape Town, where he presented the insignia of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Companions%20of%20Honour">Order of the Companions of Honour</a> to the Archbishop on behalf of the Queen. Stepping back.
In January 2020, the Duke and Duchess announced that <a href="Megxit">they were stepping back</a> from their role as senior members of the royal family, and would balance their time between the United Kingdom and North America. A statement released by the Palace confirmed that the Duke and Duchess were to become financially independent and cease to represent the Queen. The couple retain their HRH stylings but are not permitted to use them. The formal role of the Duke and Duchess was subject to a twelve-month review period, ending in March 2021. In March 2020, Harry attended the opening of the Silverstone Experience in <a href="Silverstone%20Circuit">Silverstone Circuit</a> together with racing driver <a href="Lewis%20Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a>. Harry's appearance at the museum was his final solo engagement as a senior royal before he and his wife officially stepped down on 31 March.

Sussex Royal and Archewell.
In June 2019, it was announced that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex would split from <a href="The%20Royal%20Foundation">The Royal Foundation</a> and establish their own charity foundation by the end of 2019. Nevertheless, the couple would collaborate with Harry's brother and his wife on mutual projects, such as the mental health initiative Heads Together. In July 2019, Harry and Meghan's new charity was registered in England and Wales under the title "Sussex Royal The Foundation of The Duke and Duchess of Sussex". On 21 February, it was confirmed that "<a href="Sussex%20Royal">Sussex Royal</a>" would not be used as a brand name for the couple following their withdrawal from public life. On 5 August 2020, Sussex Royal Foundation was renamed "<a href="Markle%20Windsor%20Foundation">MWX Foundation</a>" and dissolved the same day.

Representatives for the couple claimed that Sussex Royal was "managed by a board of trustees" and that "suggestion of mismanagement" directed exclusively at the Duke and Duchess would be incorrect. The commission later concluded that the foundation did not act unlawfully, but criticised the board of directors for expending a "substantial proportion of funds" to setting up and closing the charity.

The name stems from the Greek word "<a href="arche">arche</a>", which means "source of action"; the same word that inspired the name of their son. Archewell was registered in the United States. Its website was officially launched in October 2020.

Legal issues and incidents.

Former "News of the World" royal editor <a href="Clive%20Goodman">Clive Goodman</a> had previously stated that he had <a href="News%20of%20the%20World%20royal%20phone%20hacking%20scandal">hacked</a> Harry's phone on nine occasions. The IPSO rejected Harry's claim that the paper's description was "inaccurate" or "misleading". Later that month, lawyers issued a legal warning to the press after paparazzi photographs were published in the media. After his resignation from the royal family was announced, Harry appeared "to lay the blame at the feet of the press" for his decision. In March 2020, the couple took Splash UK to court after the Duchess and their son were photographed without permission during a "private family outing" while staying in Canada. The case was settled later that year with Splash UK agreeing to no longer take unauthorised photos of the family. On 20 April 2020, the Duke and Duchess announced that they would no longer cooperate with the "Daily Mail", the "Sun", the "Mirror" and the "Express".
A September 2020 article by "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>" claiming an Invictus Games fundraiser had been cancelled due to its affiliation with a competitor of Netflix, Harry's business partner, became the subject of a legal complaint issued by the Duke. Oprah interview and Twitter trolling.
Harry and his wife <a href="Oprah%20with%20Meghan%20and%20Harry">were interviewed</a> by <a href="Oprah%20Winfrey">Oprah Winfrey</a> in a television special for <a href="CBS">CBS</a>, broadcast on 7 March 2021. Meghan spoke about "stepping into life as a royal, marriage, motherhood" and "how she is handling life under intense public pressure". Harry joined her later, and the pair talked about the initial difficulties associated with their move to the United States in 2020 and their plans for the future. During the interview, Harry criticised his father's parenting style while he was trying to deal with the death of his mother. He maintained his father did not answer his calls and had cut him off financially, and he had no relationship with his brother, Prince William, stating "The relationship is space, at the moment. Time heals all things, hopefully."<ref name=independent30/12/2021></ref> There was a wide and polarised reaction to the interview.
In October 2021, Twitter analytics service Bot Sentinel released their analysis of more than 114,000 tweets about the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, as a result of which they found 83 accounts with a combined number of 187,631 followers responsible for approximately 70% of the negative content posted about the couple. The report prompted an investigation by Twitter. Twitter stated that it found no evidence of "widespread coordination" between the accounts, and said that it had taken action against users who violated Twitter's conduct policy. Bot Sentinel also released three more reports in the following months, arguing that the accounts were part of a "bot network" and a similar network could be found on YouTube. In January 2022, the BBC named Harry and Meghan among people whose photos and videos were used in fake instant profits advertisements and <a href="bitcoin">bitcoin</a>-related investment schemes.

On 18 January 2020, Buckingham Palace announced that, following their decision to <a href="Megxit">step back from royal duties</a>, from 31 March 2020 Harry and his wife would not use their "Royal Highness" styles, but as a British prince, he will not be stripped of his style and titles.
Before his marriage, Harry used Wales as his surname for military purposes and was known as "Captain Harry Wales" in such contexts. On 4 June 2015, as part of the <a href="2015%20Special%20Honours">2015 Special Honours</a>, Harry was <a href="knight">knight</a>ed by his grandmother, the Queen, for "services to the sovereign", being appointed a <a href="Knight%20Commander%20of%20the%20Royal%20Victorian%20Order">Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order</a> (KCVO).

Ancestry.
<a href="Patrilineality">Agnatically</a>, Harry is a member of the <a href="House%20of%20Gl%C3%BCcksburg">House of Glücksburg</a>, a cadet branch of the <a href="House%20of%20Oldenburg">House of Oldenburg</a>, one of Europe's oldest royal houses. Harry's paternal grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, issued <a href="House%20of%20Windsor%23Descendants%20of%20Elizabeth%20II">letters patent on 8 February 1960</a> declaring his father to be a member of the <a href="House%20of%20Windsor">House of Windsor</a>.
Ancestors on Harry's father's side include most of the royal families of Europe, and on his mother's side, the <a href="Earl%20Spencer%20%28peerage%29">Earls Spencer</a>—a cadet branch of the <a href="Spencer%20family">Spencer family</a> descended from the <a href="Earl%20of%20Sunderland">Earls of Sunderland</a>; the senior branch are now also <a href="Duke%20of%20Marlborough%20%28title%29">Dukes of Marlborough</a>; the <a href="Baron%20Fermoy">Barons Fermoy</a>; and more anciently from <a href="Henry%20FitzRoy%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Grafton">Henry FitzRoy, 1st Duke of Grafton</a>, and <a href="Charles%20Lennox%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Richmond">Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond</a>—two illegitimate sons of King <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II</a>.
Harry and his brother William descend <a href="matrilineally">matrilineally</a> from Eliza Kewark, a housekeeper for his eighteenth-century ancestor Theodore Forbes—a Scottish merchant who worked for the East India Company in <a href="Surat">Surat</a>. She is variously described in contemporary documents as "a dark-skinned native woman", "an <a href="Armenians">Armenian</a> woman from Bombay", and "Mrs. Forbesian". Genealogist <a href="William%20Addams%20Reitwiesner">William Addams Reitwiesner</a> assumed Kewark was Armenian. In June 2013, BritainsDNA announced that <a href="genealogical%20DNA%20test">genealogical DNA test</a>s on two of Harry and William's distant matrilineal cousins confirm Kewark was matrilineally of Indian descent.
